civilopediaText.text: The Archon War raged across the land, countless gods clashing for dominion.
When the dust settled, only seven remained, each taking a throne over a corner of the world.
The defeated gods left behind ruins, beasts, and remnants of their power—scars that mortals must endure.
Shrines were raised to the victors, and their visions became the bond between Archon and mortal.
With the warss end, humanity began rebuilding under the protection, or dominion, of the Seven.
Though peace returned,  whispers of the Abyss began to stir. From ruins and forbidden knowledge, secret orders plotted against the rule of the Seven.
The Archon War may have ended, but the scars it left run deep, and the world is forever changed.
With the Archon War ended, a fragile peace descended upon the land. The Seven guided their nations, shaping the laws, culture, and faith of humanity.
Cities expanded, trade routes opened, and great shrines and monuments were raised in honor of the Archons.
Yet shadows lingered. Defeated gods and their followers turned bitter, harboring hatred for the new order.
Beneath the earth, hidden cults and exiles began weaving the first true foundations of the Abyss, plotting in silence as the world above celebrated peace.
The Seven Archons turned their attention toward building their nations, guiding mortals with their ideals and power.
It was an age of great construction — walls, harbors, temples, and cities rose from the earth under divine and mortal hands alike.
Mortals began shaping their own cultures, laws, and ways of life, even as divine influence lingered.
The young nations began to expand their borders, exploring the lands beyond their first cities.
Trade routes and roads connected settlements, allowing knowledge, goods, and culture to spread further than ever before.
Conflicts arose as ambitions grew — armies were trained, and alliances were tested.
It was a time of discovery, ambition, and the strengthening of mortal kingdoms under the guidance of their Archons.
The nations matured, their people no longer merely guided by divine will but by their own laws, philosophies, and ambitions.
Arts, culture, and scholarship thrived as mortals sought meaning beyond survival and conquest.
Diplomacy, alliances, and rivalries between nations began shaping the balance of power across the land.
It was an age where humanity itself began to shine, showing strength and vision apart from the Archons.
The uneasy balance between nations began to fray as ambitions grew unchecked.
Old rivalries resurfaced, and whispers of the Abyss reached every corner of the world.
In secret, scholars and outcasts delved into forbidden knowledge, unraveling truths not meant for mortal eyes.
Technological and military innovations accelerated, not for prosperity, but for preparation.
It was an age of sharpening blades, uneasy truces, and shadows gathering beneath the earth — a storm soon to come.
The world is thrown into chaos once more, as powers both divine and mortal converge in open conflict.
The Abyss, with the Loom of Fate nearly complete, threatens to unravel the Ley Lines themselves.
Each nation looks to its Archon or chosen champion, rallying for what may be the final struggle of an age.
Ancient rivalries burn brighter than ever, as alliances fracture and empires march to war.
This is no mere clash of nations — it is a struggle for the soul of Teyvat itself.
